title: Alex Hunt Has Only One Arm, Yet He Is Competing With Able-Bodied Tennis Players And Winning Too

Alex Hunt Has Only One Arm, Yet He Is Competing With Able-Bodied Tennis Players And Winning Too

Alex Hunt Has Only One Arm, Yet He Is Competing With Able-Bodied Tennis Players And Winning Too

When Alex Hunt was born he did not have the lower portion of his left arm. So a sport like tennis was something that could be easily ruled out right? Wrong! He fought all the odds to make it to the court and is standing toe to toe with able-bodied players.

Hunt uses a prosthetic on his left hand to toss the ball up. His right arm generates enough pace and power for the ball to travel far and wide. No wonder he can be a handful even for those who use 2 hands.

Pacific news

Hunt first made waves in 2017 when he won a match in the main draw of an ITF event for the first time. He beat Christopher Cajigan 6-0, 6-0 without dropping a game. As a result he secured his first world ranking point and this was after a wild card entry into the tournament.

He had earlier proved his mettle when he defeated 9 Thai players to enter the semis of a local Thailand tennis event. The presence of strong nerves ensure a good forehand while he plays back-hand one handed to compensate.

Hunt was the youngest of three brothers and grew up in a sheep station in Wakefield, New Zealand. After finishing school, he played at college level and not once did his handicap limit his range of success.

Pacific News

His idol is Roger Federer. Despite not having a sponsor or a coach, Hunt is giving it his all. His aim is to play all over the world and earn as many ATP points as possible. But the greatest battle he has won is off the court, that ofg adversity.Hunt is still fighting the good fight, and sportspersons like him are proof how sport isthe ultimate triumph of the human spirit. Where there is a will there is always a way.
